Award.AwardTitle: REU site: REU Site in Materials and Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
A total of thirty undergraduate physics majors are engaged in research in materials and astrophysics for ten weeks during the summers of 2010, 2011, and 2012. Students are recruited nationally to the REU site, with preference for students from the Western states, students from underrepresented groups, and students from institutions with limited research facilities. Students live in the dorms at UNLV, eat their meals together, and form a cohesive social group. Student participate in research in the state-of-the-art laboratories at UNLV. In addition, students will have an opportunity to visit major national facilities at the Nevada Test Site and at either the Advanced Light Source (ALS) at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory or the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory. Many of the students will participate in research at the ALS or APS, using UNLV's research facilities. Thus students will thus get a research experience in both "small science" and "big science". Students from a small college are very impressed when they visit or work at a massive DOE facility. Many of today's students will work at world-class national research facilities. Becoming familiar with the world of Big Science is important for the students'future careers. A student who has had a research experience is more likely to attend graduate school. In recent years, 64% of the graduating students have gone on to graduate school in physics or a closely related field. The program encourages promising students to choose careers in science and engineering.

During the summers of 2010-2012, REU students work on research projects, including experiments on the properties of matter under extremely high pressure (millions of atmospheres, comparable to conditions in the center of the Earth), using the facilities of UNLV's High Pressure Science and Engineering Center, which operates laboratories at UNLV and a beamline at the Advanced Photon Source. Other students work on projects in astrophysics, such as analysis of Gamma Ray Bursts, the most violent events in the universe; or computer modeling of the physics of accretion disks near black holes. Student projects often result in student co-authorship of presentations at professional meetings or publications in the professional scientific literature.

Project Outcomes Report 

 REU Site in Materials and Astrophysics

University of Nevada La Vegas

Award Number 1005247

Undergraduate student physics majors were recruited nationally to participate in an REU site at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV) during the summers of 2010-2013. During the grant interval, 30 undergraduate students were supported by the REU grant, joining another 9 physics students who were supported by the High Pressure Science and Engineering Center (HPSEC), and two students who were supported by both REU and HPSEC.. The summer REU program is quite selective: in a typical summer, over 100 student applications were received for only 10 positions. Students worked in the research laboratories, including the excellent research facilities of the High Pressure Science and Engineering Center at UNLV. The research facilities can create pressures of a million atmospheres, a regime where the properties of materials are often dramatically different from their properties at the familiar atmospheric pressure. All students visited UNLV's facilities at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) at Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois, one of the brightest sources of hard X-rays in the world. UNLV shares a beamline at the APS, which guaranteed that REU students could use the X-rays at the APS for their student projects. At the end of the summer, REU students presented their research results at  a well-attended poster session. REU students were co-authors on presentations at professional meetings  and manuscripts published in the peer-reviewed scientific literature. In addition, students participated in a weekly seminar series, which addressed many topics of interest to undergraduate students, including: research ethics, poster preparation, careers in science, graduate school admission, and other topics that are important for their careers.   The intellectual merit is guaranteed by the exposure to scrutiny of the student projects at the UNLV poster session, and in presentations at meetings and in publications in the peer-reviewed scientific literature with REU students as co-authors. The broader impact is that students gained confidence and independence during their summer experience, and were more likely to attend graduate school than students who have not had a research experience. Students selected for the REU program were often from home institutions without major research programs, so the REU program provided an opportunity to have a research experience that they would not have otherwise. Special attention was paid to students from underrepresented groups.
